repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Agricultural Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project fin Uganda are as follows: overall
            outcome of the project rated as satisfactory; and
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower also rated as
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: (a) impressive achievements were made under the
            project, particularly in the areas of policy reforms in the
            liberalization of the coffee sub-sector, and in facilitating
            the establishment of institutions for coffee development
            (UCDA) and national research (NARO); (b) the survival of
            Coffee Marketing Board (CMB) was necessary to avoid a total
            collapse in the industry at the time of deregulation, and
            this was reflected in the project's design. When market
            reforms are being introduced, it is important that there is
            a phased entry of private sector participation; and (c)
            capacity building and gaining experience in procurement is
            critical for smooth implementation and takes time.
            Centralizing procurement for a multi-agency implemented
            project helped in this area.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Agricultural Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Agricultural
            Sector Adjustment Credit Project are: (a) to facilitate
            financial stabilization by controlling credit expansion
            through improved institutional arrangements for financing
            coffee crop procurement, and financial restructuring of
            marketing intermediaries; and (b) to promote agricultural
            growth and diversification by creating competitive systems
            for processing and marketing of export crops through reform
            of marketing institutions.  The project consists of two
            components.  Under the adjustment component the credit
            finances agricultural sector recurrent imports in support of
            significant policy reforms in the sector.  Actions to be
            monitored include transfer of the responsibility for crop
            financing from the Central Bank to commercial banks,
            restructuring of the Coffee Marketing Board (CMB) as a
            commercial marketing organization, rehabilitation of
            cooperative unions, broadening of private sector
            participation in coffee exports, reforms of the export
            taxation system to introduce trade incentives, and
            establishment of a semiautonomous national agricultural
            research organization.  Under the investment component the
            credit finances: (a) a Head-Start Program for Agricultural
            Research and Extension to implement high priority
            activities; (b) support for a program for land policy
            research; (c) a program to strengthen agricultural sector
            planning; (d) technical assistance for coffee subsector
            management; and (e) institutional support for
            projectcoordination and monitoring.
